Questions_JSON:
```json
{
  "Questions": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "question_type": "T005 - Multiple Choice",
      "question_text": "What TWO essential tasks does Mark advise Sarah to complete *immediately* after arriving on campus at the Student Welcome Centre?",
      "options": {
        "A": "Obtain her student identification card.",
        "B": "Collect her accommodation keys.",
        "C": "Finalize her course registration.",
        "D": "Attend the general orientation welcome talk.",
        "E": "Sign up for a sports club."
      }
    }
  ],
  "Answers": [
    "A",
    "C"
  ],
  "Transcript": "Mark: Welcome to Brightwater University, Sarah! I’m Mark, your campus guide for today. Ready for the grand tour?

Sarah: Absolutely, Mark! Thanks for doing this. I'm really excited but a bit overwhelmed by the size of everything.

Mark: Perfectly normal! That’s why we do these tours. We’ll start here, right by the main gate, and our first crucial stop is the Student Welcome Centre, just across this plaza. It’s that modern glass building over there.

Sarah: Okay, good to know where to start.

Mark: Right. So, when you actually arrive on campus for your move-in day, this will be your absolute first port of call. Before you even think about unpacking or finding your room, you need to come here. This is where you’ll complete your initial course registration if you haven't finalised it online yet – it’s a quick check-in to confirm your modules and timetable. And, most importantly, you collect your student identification card here. You won't be able to access the library, labs, or even pick up your accommodation keys without it, so it's vital. Make sure you have your acceptance letter and some form of photo ID with you.

Sarah: So, registration and the ID card are the absolute top priorities?

Mark: Exactly. Once those are sorted, you can then pick up your official orientation pack, which will have your specific faculty welcome talk schedule and details about all the other introductory events. You'll also get directions to your residential hall and collect your room key from a separate desk here, but only after you’ve got your ID.

Sarah: Got it. That makes sense. What's next on the tour?

Mark: Next, we'll head over to the main library, the 'Knowledge Hub' as we call it. It's just a five-minute walk from here, past the clock tower. It’s open 24/7 during term time and has fantastic resources, quiet study zones, and group project rooms. You can book those online. They also offer workshops on academic writing and research skills.

Sarah: That sounds great. I'll probably spend a lot of time there.

Mark: Most students do! From the library, we’ll cut through the main quad to the Student Union building. That’s the real heart of campus social life. Downstairs, you’ve got the main dining hall, a café, and the campus shop. Upstairs are the offices for all the student societies – we have over 200, from chess club to drama society, environmental activism, and even a skydiving club! This is also where you'll find the Student Support Services, offering advice on everything from finance to wellbeing and careers.

Sarah: Wow, two hundred clubs! I was hoping to join a sports team.

Mark: Excellent! For sports clubs, you'll need to head to the Brightwater Sports Centre, which we'll visit next. It's about a ten-minute walk from the Student Union, on the far side of campus. It has an Olympic-sized swimming pool, a fully-equipped gym, squash courts, and several outdoor pitches. Try-outs for competitive teams usually happen in the first two weeks of term, and there are also plenty of recreational leagues and fitness classes you can join without needing to be super competitive. You can sign up for those at the Sports Centre reception.

Sarah: Perfect. I'll make sure to check that out. Is there anything else about initial steps I should know?

Mark: Well, once you've settled into your accommodation and attended your faculty's welcome talk, you'll want to explore your department's specific facilities. Most departments have their own common rooms, computer labs, and sometimes even small libraries. The general orientation will cover most of it, but don't hesitate to ask your department head or academic advisor for details. Also, make sure to activate your university email and check it regularly for important announcements. We'll be walking past the IT services building later, which can help with any tech issues.

Sarah: Okay, so, Student Welcome Centre first for ID and registration, then library, then Student Union, then Sports Centre. Got it. This has been really helpful, Mark. Thank you.

Mark: My pleasure, Sarah! We'll just finish up by walking past the main residential halls so you can get a feel for them. Any other questions so far?",
  "Diagram": ""
}
```

```json
{
  "Questions": [
    "1. The new *Quantum Library* is celebrated for its extensive collection and specialized ___________.",
    "2. Students seeking help with job applications and interview practice should visit the __________.",
    "3. According to Mark, the university places a strong emphasis on fostering a sense of ___________ among its students.",
    "4. First-year undergraduates are primarily housed in modern purpose-built __________.",
    "5. The *Innovation Hub* provides students with cutting-edge facilities to develop their projects, particularly in ___________.",
    "6. Sophie is advised to consider attending a ___________ for a more in-depth look at her chosen field.",
    "7. The Student Union organises a wide range of extracurricular activities and manages a popular __________."
  ],
  "Answers": [
    "digital resources",
    "Careers Service",
    "community spirit",
    "residential blocks",
    "sustainable technology",
    "departmental open day",
    "student café"
  ],
  "Transcript": "Mark: Welcome, Sophie, to the University of Westford! I'm Mark, one of our senior campus guides. Are you excited to see everything today?
Sophie: Absolutely, Mark! It's my first time visiting, and I'm really keen to get a feel for the place. I've heard so much about Westford.
Mark: Excellent! We're quite proud of our campus. We’ll start here at the main quadrangle, then move towards the academic buildings, explore some student facilities, and finally wrap up near the sports complex. Feel free to ask any questions as we go.
Sophie: Sounds perfect.
Mark: Alright, straight ahead, that impressive glass and steel structure is the *Quantum Library*. It's not just our central hub for learning; it's a testament to our commitment to cutting-edge research and accessible knowledge. It underwent a significant expansion three years ago.
Sophie: It looks massive! What are the main features of the new section?
Mark: Well, beyond the sheer increase in physical book capacity, the expansion focused heavily on enhancing our **digital resources**. We now have dedicated virtual reality labs for certain disciplines, an extensive e-journal database, and advanced multimedia suites. It's designed to cater to modern research methodologies, offering quiet study zones alongside collaborative spaces for group projects.
Sophie: That sounds really progressive. I'm studying computer science, so access to strong digital resources is crucial for me.
Mark: Absolutely. And you'll find subject-specific librarians who are experts in curating those resources for your field, ready to assist with complex research queries.

Mark: Let's head over towards the Guild Building. This is a real focal point for student support. On the ground floor, you'll find the **Careers Service**. They offer invaluable assistance, from helping students craft compelling CVs and cover letters to conducting mock interviews and connecting them with internships and graduate schemes. They also host regular career fairs with leading employers from various sectors, both national and international.
Sophie: That's a huge relief. I'm always worried about job prospects after university, especially in such a competitive market.
Mark: It’s a common concern, Sophie, but our Careers Service has an outstanding track record. They work tirelessly to ensure our graduates are well-prepared for the competitive job market, and they maintain strong, enduring links with industry partners, which often translates into excellent opportunities for our students even before they graduate.

Mark: Now, as we walk past the Student Union building, I want to touch on something I believe is truly unique about Westford: our inherent **community spirit**. While we are a large university, there's a palpable sense of belonging here. We actively foster an inclusive environment where students from diverse backgrounds feel genuinely welcome and supported. From the numerous student societies to the peer mentoring schemes and our dedicated welfare services, we really emphasize connectivity and mutual support. It's not just about academic excellence; it's about personal growth, holistic development, and creating lifelong connections. That's a philosophy we hold very dear and continually strive to strengthen.
Sophie: That sounds really welcoming. I'm hoping to find a place where I can make good friends and feel settled, rather than feeling lost in a big institution.
Mark: You absolutely will. We pride ourselves on that aspect, and it's something consistently highlighted in our student satisfaction surveys.

Mark: Moving on, if you look straight ahead, you'll see a cluster of modern buildings. These are some of our **residential blocks**. For first-year undergraduates, we guarantee accommodation, and most of it is purpose-built and situated right here on the main campus or very close by, typically just a five-minute walk from lectures. They're equipped with en-suite facilities and shared communal kitchens, offering a blend of privacy and social interaction. It's a great way to meet people and integrate into university life right from the start, forging those initial friendships.
Sophie: That’s good to know. I was wondering about accommodation options and how easy it would be to find a place.
Mark: We also have some postgraduate options and comprehensive private rented accommodation listings through the university portal for subsequent years, but the first year is all about making that transition as smooth and worry-free as possible.

Mark: Over to our left, this striking architectural marvel is the *Innovation Hub*. This facility is truly at the forefront of our research capabilities and entrepreneurial endeavours. It’s where interdisciplinary teams, often comprising both students and faculty, collaborate on groundbreaking projects. We’ve invested heavily in state-of-the-art labs, prototyping workshops, and dedicated incubator spaces here.
Sophie: What kind of projects are they working on? It looks incredibly advanced.
Mark: A vast array, but there’s a particular focus on **sustainable technology** and artificial intelligence applications, especially those with societal impact. For instance, there's a team currently developing smart urban farming solutions to address food security, and another working on advanced materials for renewable energy storage systems. It's designed to encourage entrepreneurial thinking and swiftly translate academic discoveries into tangible, real-world impact.
Sophie: That’s fascinating, especially the sustainable technology aspect. My computer science course touches on that, and I'm very interested in environmental issues.
Mark: Indeed, there are many opportunities for students across different faculties to get involved, even at undergraduate level, through research internships or specific project modules. It's a very dynamic environment.

Mark: We're now approaching the Computer Science Department building, your potential academic home! I won't take you inside today as it's a general campus tour, but I highly recommend you attend a **departmental open day** if you're serious about applying. These events offer a much more in-depth experience: you'll meet the professors, see the specific labs and computing facilities, and even sit in on a mini-lecture or participate in a workshop. It's the best way to truly understand the curriculum, the teaching philosophy, and the research culture within your chosen field.
Sophie: That’s a great idea. I’ll definitely look into that. It would be good to speak directly with some of the lecturers and current students.
Mark: Absolutely. And you can get a feel for the student experience within your particular department, which can be quite nuanced and different from the broader university atmosphere.

Mark: Let's make our way back towards the Student Union building, where we started. I want to highlight one more key aspect of student life. Besides housing the Careers Service and numerous administrative offices, the Student Union is the vibrant hub for all extracurricular activities. They manage over 200 clubs and societies – everything from academic societies like the robotics club to sports clubs, debate teams, and cultural groups. And right next to the main common room, you’ll find a very popular **student café**. It’s more than just a place to grab a coffee; it’s a vibrant social hub, perfect for casual meetings, quick study breaks, or just hanging out with friends between lectures in a relaxed atmosphere.
Sophie: That sounds like a great place to relax and meet new people, which is important when you're far from home.
Mark: It really is. It’s purposefully designed to be a comfortable, welcoming space, reflecting the inclusive ethos we strive for across the entire university community.

Mark: Well, Sophie, that concludes our main campus tour. I hope it's given you a comprehensive overview of what life at the University of Westford is like. Do you have any final questions for me or anything you'd like to revisit?
Sophie: No, Mark, thank you so much! It's been incredibly informative, and I feel much more confident about applying now. The digital resources in the library sound fantastic, and I'm definitely going to look into that departmental open day. I really appreciate your time.
Mark: My pleasure, Sophie. We hope to see you here next year!"
}
```
